Revealing the specific role of sulfide and nano-alumina in composite solid-state electrolytes for performance-reinforced ether-nitrile copolymers Haoyang Yuan Investigation Methodology Formal analysis Writing – original draft a Changhao Tian Methodology Writing – review & editing a Mengyuan Song Methodology a Wenjun Lin Investigation b Tao Huang Funding acquisition Writing – review & editing Validation Project administration Supervision b ⁎ Aishui Yu Conceptualization Funding acquisition Writing – review & editing Validation Project administration Supervision a ⁎ a Department of Chemistry, Collaborative Innovation Center of Chemistry for Energy Materials, Shanghai Key Laboratory of Molecular Catalysis and Innovative Materials, Institute of New Energy, Fudan University, Shanghai 200438, China Department of Chemistry Collaborative Innovation Center of Chemistry for Energy Materials Shanghai Key Laboratory of Molecular Catalysis and Innovative Materials Institute of New Energy Fudan University Shanghai 200438 China Department of Chemistry, Collaborative Innovation Center of Chemistry for Energy Materials, Shanghai Key Laboratory of Molecular Catalysis and Innovative Materials, Institute of New Energy, Fudan University, Shanghai 200438, China b Laboratory of Advanced Materials, Fudan University, Shanghai 200438, China Laboratory of Advanced Materials Fudan University Shanghai 200438 China Laboratory of Advanced Materials, Fudan University, Shanghai 200438, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract The composite solid-state electrolyte using dual inorganic fillers with ether-nitrile copolymer exhibits a more stable cathode and anode interface evolution in the distribution of relaxation time during cycling. Composite solid-state electrolytes represent a critical pathway that balances the interface compatibility and lithium-ion conductivity in all-solid-state batteries. The quest for stable and highly ion-conductive combinations between polymers and fillers is vital, but blind attempts are often made due to a lack of understanding of the mechanisms involved in the interaction between polymers and fillers. Herein, we employ in-situ polymerization to prepare a polymer based on an ether-nitrile copolymer with high cathode stability as the foundation and discuss the performance enhancement mechanisms of argyrodite and nano-alumina. With 1% content of sulfide interacting with the polymer at the two-phase interface, the local enhancement of lithium-ion migration capability can be achieved, avoiding the reduction in capacity due to the low ion conductivity of the passivation layer during cycling. The capacity retention after 50 cycles at 0.5 C increases from 83.5% to 94.4%. Nano-alumina, through anchoring the anions and interface inhibition functions, eventually poses an initial discharge capacity of 136.8 mA h g−1 at 0.5 C and extends the cycling time to 1000 h without short-circuiting in lithium metal batteries. Through the combined action of dual fillers on the composite solid-state electrolyte, promising insights are provided for future material design. Keywords Composite solid-state electrolytes Lithium metal anode Dual fillers Interfacial ionic conduction Inert nano-alumina 1 Introduction The flammability of liquid electrolytes is a pressing concern in the energy and power markets [1–4]. If solid-state battery systems are established, they have the potential to address safety issues, liberating electrode materials from the voltage range limitations imposed by the decomposition voltage of liquid electrolytes and further enhancing energy density. The current challenges lie in the incompatibility of inorganic materials at interfaces and the low ionic conductivity of organic polymers, making both difficult to apply at present [5]. Composite solid-state electrolytes, combining the strengths of both, offer a potential solution. Various composite systems, employing materials like silicon dioxide [6], alumina [7], natrium superionic conductor [3,8,9], and garnet as fillers [10–13], along with commonly used polymers such as polyethylene oxide (PEO) [12,14–16], polypropylene carbonate (PPC) [9,17], and polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) as matrices [8,18–20], have been extensively reported. It is widely believed that oxide fillers contribute to the improvement of lithium-ion migration and mechanical properties of separators. However, researches on composite systems based on higher ion-conducting sulfide have been lacking due to the lower thermodynamic stability of sulfides [21]. Moreover, to address the issue of solid–solid contact in solid-state electrolytes, in-situ polymerization has been increasingly employed in battery assembly. The wetting of the solid particles by the liquid precursor and in-situ curing result in a void-free interface, significantly reducing impedance. Materials including polyvinylene carbonate (PVCa) [10], polycaprolactone [22], polyacrylonitrile (PAN) [23], and poly(poly (ethylene glycol) methyl ether methacrylate) (P(PEGMA)) have been attempted [24,25]. By selecting and controlling the polymerization monomers, it is possible to design polymers for solid-state electrolytes with more targeted performance. Furthermore, since in-situ polymerization avoids the use of polar solvents, it has significant implications for the synthesis of sulfide composite solid-state electrolytes. Composite solid-state electrolytes like Li10SnP2S12/PVCa and Li10GeP2S12/poly(ethylene glycol) diglycidyl ether have already been reported [26,27]. However, overall, these designs are mainly based on the simple combination of the basic properties of each material, and there is limited discussion on the lithium-ion conduction and interface evolution mechanisms of composite solid-state electrolytes. Conventional ether compounds are widely accepted for their ability to coordinate and conduct lithium ions while stabilizing the lithium anode. To enhance the stability of the LiNi0.6Co0.2Mn0.2O2 cathode (NCM), we copolymerized PEGMA with acrylonitrile [28,29]. In this study, using this copolymer as a matrix, we investigated the specific mechanisms of the additive of highly ion-conductive sulfide Li6PS5Cl (LPSC) and inert nano-alumina. Argyrodite, with higher ionic conductivity (>1 mS cm−1) than oxide solid-state electrolytes, is considered as a filler for copolymers to achieve improved ionic conductivity with less additive. The interface of sulfides is more conducive to ion exchange with polymers, promoting the dissociation of lithium salts and polymer coordination for ion conduction. The enhanced lithium-ion exchange at the interface between the two promotes lithium ion transport and facilitates the formation of a more stable electrode passivation layer. This increases the capacity retention from 83.5% to 94.4% over 50 cycles at 0.5 C. Although nano-alumina does not directly participate in lithium-ion transport, its anchoring effect on anions increases the lithium-ion transference number from 0.30 to 0.54. The improved mechanical properties mitigated lithium dendrite growth. The full-cell achieved 1000 h of operation without short-circuiting, with an initial discharge specific capacity of 136.8 mA h g−1, retaining 91.4 mA h g−1 after 500 cycles. This work provides insights into the mechanisms of dual fillers in composite solid-state electrolytes, filling the gap in sulfide fillers and offering guidance for the overall design of future batteries. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of solid-state electrolytes All solid materials are used after vacuum drying. For PEO, 40 wt% LiTFSI (Aladdin) and PEO (Aladdin) were dissolved in N,N-dimethylformamide (Adamas) where EO/Li is 16:1 and then kept in an oven at 80 °C for 12 h. For in-situ polymerized copolymer, the same mass fraction of lithium salts and 0.5 wt.% azobisisobutyronitrile (AIBN, J&K scientific) were solved in a mixture of acrylonitrile (Aladdin) and poly(ethylene glycol) methyl ether methacrylate (PEGMA, average Mn = 950, Rhawn). After heating at 60 °C for 2 h and 80 °C for 3 h, A1M, A2M, and A3M (the volume content of acrylonitrile is 10%, 20%, and 30%, respectively) were synthesized. To obtain composite solid-state electrolytes, additives are mixed in precursors and other processes are the same. If only x wt% of LPSC (Enpower) is added, it is named LxAnM. AyAnM means that only y wt% nano-alumina is added. If it is a binary filler, it is called LxAyAnM. 2.2 Materials characterization Thermo Fisher Scientific Nicolet iS50 was employed to record data of FT-IR in the range of 400–4000 cm−1 with ATR mode. 1H nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) was tested on Bruker AVANCEIII 400M after solving in dimethyl sulfoxide-d6 (99.9 at% D, Sigma-Aldrich). X-ray diffraction (XRD, Bruker D8 Discover) was utilized to get structure information. Field emission scanning electron microscopy (Hitachi-S4800) was used to observe the microscopic morphology. Surface elemental composition was analyzed by XPS using PerkinElmer PHI5000C. Raman spectra were recorded by HORIBA XploRA. 2.3 Electrochemical tests All batteries were assembled in the Ar-filled glove box using CR2025 type coin cells. NCM sheets (loading mass: 2.5 mg cm−2) were synthesized by a previously reported method [30]. The cellulose membrane moistened with 30 μL precursor solution was placed between the NCM cathode and lithium metal anode to complete the battery assembly. After thermal polymerization, cells were cycled in a voltage range in 2.8–4.3 V (1 C = 180 mA g−1) using LAND-CT2001A (Wuhan LANHE Technology Co., Ltd.). The data of DC-IR was obtained by charging or discharging 10 s at different rates and resting 30 minutes after charging to 3.7 V and holding 1 h. Metrohm Autolab M204 was employed for electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS), cyclic voltammetry (CV), and linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) at set temperature. To conduct ionic conductivity of electrolytes, EIS of symmetric stainless steel (SS) cells was measured in a frequency range of 0.1 Hz to 7 MHz (ΔV = 10 mV). Ionic conductivity (σ) was calculated using the following formula. (1) σ = l / R S where l represents the distance between blocking electrodes, R stands for electrochemical impedance, and S is the area of conductive area. CV is measured over the full-cell operating voltage range with a scan speed of 0.1 mV s−1. LSV uses a Li//SS cell to measure the electrochemical window in the interval 2.5–6 V with a scan speed of 1 mV s−1. The lithium-ion transference number (t Li +) is calculated from the polarization current of a lithium symmetrical battery at a polarization voltage of 10 mV. (2) t L i + = I S Δ V - I 0 R 0 / I 0 Δ V - I S R S where the current and impedance before polarization are I 0 and R 0 respectively, and after polarization they are I S and R S. DRT analysis is completed through GEIS with the help of the free software DRTtools [31]. 2.4 Calculations To obtain the energy levels of organic molecules, Orca 5.0.4 is used for geometry optimization through B3LYP-D3(BJ)/6-311+G (d, p) [32–36]. CP2K 2023.1 program is used for calculations related to inorganic crystal structures [37]. Based on the hybrid Gaussian plane wave (GPW) [38], DZVP–MOLOPT–SR–GTH basis set [39,40], and D3 correction method of Grimme et al [41], we constructed a structure containing a 15 Å vacuum layer, and then performed geometric optimization of the molecular structure before and after binding. There is a 400 Ry (Rydberg) plane-wave cutoff and the Brillouin zone is sampled at the Γ-point only. The binding energy (BE) is calculated by the following formula (3) BE = E all - ∑ i E i where E all is the total energy after combination, and E i represents the single energy of each substance. For AIMD, we use a 2 × 1 × 1 argyrodite supercell and a copolymer chain where the simulation box size is 20.56 Å × 10.28 Å × 39.60 Å with canonical ensemble (NVT) conditions imposed by a Nose-Hoover thermostat [42], where the temperature is 330 K and the pressure is 1 bar. In the structure, the two bottom layers of argyrodite are fixed. The step size during simulation is 1 fs. Multiwfn, VESTA and VMD are used for visualization processing [43–45]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and characterization of copolymer Based on structurally extensible PEGMA, acrylonitrile was able to copolymerize to enhance chemical stability. As a lower HOMO level means a stable electrolyte that does not easily react with the cathode [46], DFT calculations demonstrated a reduction in the HOMO level after copolymerization (Fig. S1). The schematic diagram of the in-situ polymerization process is illustrated in Fig. 1 (a). A cellulose membrane is utilized as an insulator to prevent short circuits between the anode and cathode during the encapsulation process. The pre-prepared precursor solution is dripped onto the cellulose and the curing of the blending system is accomplished (Fig. S2a and b) through the thermal initiation of AIBN. The synthesized copolymer can be described as comb-like, incorporating side chains with ether bonds that can be used for lithium-ion coordination and main chains with cyano groups that probably repair transient metal oxide cathode defects by coordination [28], as shown in Fig. 1(b). Fourier transform infrared spectra (FT-IR, Fig. 1c) confirm the preservation of alkyl groups, ether bonds, and ester groups in copolymers. The cyano at 2240 cm−1 can also be observed upon magnification. Unfortunately, due to lithium-ion coordination with carbonyl groups, the transmittance peaks of C=C bonds are obscured so it is difficult to directly judge the occurrence of polymerization reaction here [47]. Therefore, the completeness of the polymerization reaction was characterized by 1H NMR (Fig. S3), where hydrogens on unsaturated carbon greater than 5 ppm shift to higher fields after copolymerization. Polyacrylonitrile obsesses a high glass transition temperature, resulting in lower ionic conductivity compared to many kinds of ether-based polymers [48]. The ionic conductivity of the copolymer also follows a similar trend of decreasing ionic conductivity with an excessive proportion of acrylonitrile (Fig. S4a–d). We also observed that the brittleness of polyacrylonitrile is evident in copolymers with a high cyano groups proportion during lithium deposition and stripping tests, where from A1M to A3M, the polarization voltage of lithium symmetric cells increased from 80 to 170 mV, and the cycling time decreased from 800 to 260 h (Fig. S5). In Fig. 1(d), on the one hand, the non-copolymerized P(PEGMA) and the copolymer with only 5% acrylonitrile exhibit significant instability before 4.5 V. On the other hand, although A2M and A3M exhibit a better electrochemical window compared to A1M (4.9 and 4.7 V, respectively), adding a rational amount of cyano groups to increase high-voltage stability is a more reliable method, thereby preventing excessively low ionic conductivity and instability of lithium metal anode. 3.2 Conductive enhancement mechanism of LPSC As shown in Fig. S4(a), the copolymer exhibits a relatively high electrochemical impedance. Despite employing PEGMA with the maximum molecular weight that can be liquefied under ambient conditions, the ether chains in the oligomer are still too short compared to other ether polymers. Although the growth of ether bonds under fully activated conditions is favorable for lithium-ion conduction (Fig. S4e), the hindrance to lithium-ion coordination conduction persists, even at elevated temperatures, due to the relatively short length of the ether chains in the oligomer. Therefore, we opted for sulfide with high ionic conductivity as additives. After the addition of sulfide, there is no apparent difference in the external appearance compared to before (Fig. S2c and d). Microscopically, after polymerization, a relatively smooth surface is formed compared to the porous cellulose membrane (Fig. 2a–e). FT-IR (Fig. 1c) and EDS (energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy, Fig. S6) confirm the integrity of the molecular chain structure and the stable presence of the added argyrodite, respectively. Crucially, there is no polymer degradation catalyzed by sulfide, as is easily the case with carbonate-based polymers because of poor thermodynamic stability. It is easy to grasp that a higher content of sulfide will lead to a higher ionic conductivity (Fig. 2 f). Unlike traditional composite solid-state electrolytes, oxides can maintain chemical stability in the range of 5% to 20% [11,49]. As shown in Fig. 2(g), the electrochemical window of the sulfide composite solid-state electrolyte decreases by 0.2 V when the sulfide ratio increases from 1% to 2%. Although L2A1M’s electrochemical window remains around 4.5 V, the actual cycling performance is not outstanding, considering that the half-cell used in LSV may not reflect the stability of the full-cell electrochemical cycling. L2A1M’s initial discharge specific capacity was 120.6 mA h g−1 at 0.5 C, but it was only 62.3 mA h g−1 after 100 cycles, and the coulombic efficiency dropped to 89%, showing poor electrochemical stability (Fig. S7). This means that a 1% addition is a limitation to prevent internal degradation. As mentioned in the previous section, the brittleness of the film-like polyacrylonitrile, low ionic conductivity, and the instability of the lithium anode with cyano groups collectively result in shorter cycle times for the high-cyanide copolymer in lithium symmetric cells. A similar situation is observed after the addition of sulfides. L1A1M exhibits lower polarization voltage and longer cycling time compared to L1A2M (849 h for L1A2M, over 1000 h for L1A1M in Fig. S8). Furthermore, internal microcracks caused by brittleness accelerate lithium dendrite growth. Even slightly higher current densities can cause short circuits in the battery assembled with L1A2M. This is also the reason why L1A1M can perform better in rate tests, while L1A2M is prone to twists and turns in the charging curve. L1A1M showed a discharge specific capacity of 137.1 mA h g−1 in 0.1 C, 131.2 mA h g−1 in 0.2 C, 112.3 mA h g−1 in 0.33 C, and 84.9 mA h g−1 in 0.5 C and L1A2M presented poor lithium-ion conduction that is 129.3 mA h g−1 in 0.1 C, 124.4 mA h g−1 in 0.2 C, 92.6 mA h g−1 in 0.33 C, and 54.5 mA h g−1 in 0.5 C (Fig. S9a–d). By enhancing the ionic conductivity through the addition of sulfide, a significant reduction in electrochemical polarization of the composite solid-state electrolyte is achieved. DC-IR (direct current internal resistance) can show the impedance of lithium-ion batteries during operation. The results of DC-IR tests for A1M and L1A1M are shown in Fig. 2(h–k). Clearly, as the current rate increases from 0.025 to 1 C, the overpotential for L1A1M is lower than that for A1M whose overpotential exceeds 1V and when the rate is greater than 0.5 C, lithium-ion transfer under this condition cannot be achieved at all. Linear fits of voltage versus current reveal that the slopes differ by almost an order of magnitude. It is important to note that the two curves corresponding to charge and discharge are not symmetrical where the discharge curve poses a steeper slope, attributed to the difference in the conductivity of the cathode and anode materials. Since sulfides never be favored for their interface stability, the optimization primarily arises from enhanced internal ion transport. Another piece of phenomena is the discovery of larger oxidation–reduction peak currents in L1A1M during CV cycling (Fig. S10a and b). The NCM//Li battery assembled with the overly soft PEO experiences rapid degradation during cycling, and the coulombic efficiency oscillates around 90% (Fig. S11a). The non-copolymerized polymer (P(PEGMA)) with an excess of ether groups exhibits a capacity retention rate of only 72.3% after 50 cycles at 0.5 C (Fig. S11b). After copolymerization, the more stable A1M demonstrates an improved capacity retention of 83.5% in the same test environment (Fig. 3 a). The improvement of ionic conductivity directly influences batteries’ duration. During the cycling of a battery, a small amount of electrolyte decomposes to form SEI and CEI as a passivation layer to prevent excessive decomposition. If the ionic conductivity of the electrolyte bulk phase is poor, after the formation of the passivation layer, the overall ionic conductivity will further decrease. This poor interfacial conduction is manifested as a decrease in discharge capacity. In-situ electrochemical impedance spectra can present the impedance changes with time or voltage within each cycle. In Fig. 3(b) where each horizontal line corresponds to the electrochemical impedance curve at different voltages, and the inflection point of the imaginary part of the charge transfer resistance is distinguished by the red part on the right, A1M experienced a significant impedance change during the first cycle. At 4.3 V, the impedance was close to 600 Ω, doubling the value before cycling. Though the impedance decreased upon discharging, after the first cycle, the impedance had noticeably increased. This can also be seen in the in-situ impedance spectra for the second cycle in Fig. 3(c) where the impedance before cycling was already close to 400 Ω. Moreover, due to the reduced ionic conductivity after the first cycle, the impedance change during the second cycle was more pronounced, reaching almost 900 Ω at its maximum, which is not beneficial to long-term electrochemical cycles. For L1A1M and L1A2M, the assistance of argyrodite obviously improves stability in cycling (Fig. 3d). More importantly, after a slight increase in impedance in the first cycle due to the protection of the passivation layer (Fig. 3e), the impedance of the battery in the second cycle remained essentially unchanged (Fig. 3f), which implies the stability of the electrolyte interface. Further discussion is needed on the fact that, with only 1% of sulfide mixed into the electrolyte, the increase in conductivity cannot be described that it is significant (0.0792 mS cm−1 for A1M and 0.104 mS cm−1 for L1A1M). The ionic conductivity of L1A1M also only reaches levels suitable for application (greater than 10−4 S cm−1). Therefore, the internal mechanism of action after the sulfide blending is certainly not simply due to participation in lithium-ion conduction, as the cross-interface transport between polymers and inorganic substances is highly challenging [50]. AIMD simulations were employed to consider the interaction between sulfides and copolymers. Throughout the entire simulation process (Fig. 3g), we observed that lithium ions originally coordinated with the polymer moved into the crystal interior. After 750 fs, Li–S bond was detected, indicating the exchange of lithium ions between the inorganic crystal surface and the polymer. Additionally, lithium atoms on the inorganic crystal surface were attracted and coordinated by cyano groups and ether bonds at 130 and 175 fs. It must be admitted that this implies to some extent the instability of sulfides on ether-containing polymers. But here we are more concerned about the interaction between the two, especially the movement of lithium ions under this interaction. According to previous reports [51–53], it is generally found that inorganic and organic molecules in composite solid-state electrolytes interact to achieve continuous migration of lithium ions at the interface, which has been proven by some solid-state nuclear magnetic technologies. We believe that under the action of a small amount of sulfide, the polymer will form an intermediate phase with different conductivity on the surface of the inorganic material. Unfortunately, due to the easy oxidation of sulfides in the air and the difficulty of breaking the polymer membrane into a powder, solid-state nuclear magnetic resonance is challenging to obtain effective results. However, another compelling evidence comes from Raman spectra before and after the addition of sulfides. In A1M, two peaks at 1239 and 1270 cm−1 respectively arise from the sulfonyl groups of lithium salt and the ether bonds of the copolymer (Fig. S12). After the addition of sulfides, these two peaks are found to move in opposite directions. Generally, when lithium ions coordinate, the corresponding Raman shift of the functional group increases. The increased Raman shift of the ether bond implies the coordination effect of lithium ions, while the decreased sulfonyl group confirms the detachment of lithium ions from the original molecule [54]. Additionally, as the polarizability of the sulfonyl group decreases after lithium ions de-coordinate, the corresponding peak intensity also decreases. These results are consistent with the previous computational simulation findings. The lithium exchange on the heterogeneous surface at the beginning of the cycle promotes lithium ion transport in the local region. These interactions ultimately enhance bulk-phase conduction, also explaining why excess sulfide leads to lower stability. 3.3 Interfacial optimization mechanism of nano-Al2O3 The introduction of cyano groups and sulfide has reduced the physical properties of the solid-state electrolyte. Additionally, given the small thickness of the in-situ polymerized membrane (Fig. S13), attention needs to be paid to the stability against lithium dendrites. The addition of inert oxide filler, nanoscale alumina, can be confirmed by XRD patterns (Fig. 4 a). The synthesis process is the same as before and optical images are exhibited in Fig. S2(e and f). As shown in Fig. 4(b), the electrochemical window broadened to 5.5 V, attributed to the protective effect of inert alumina. In comparison to samples without added aluminum oxide (with a lithium-ion transference number of 0.30 in Fig. S14), the lithium-ion transference number for composite solid-state electrolytes with nano-alumina increased to 0.54. This enhancement is attributed to the strong binding affinity of aluminum oxide for LiTFSI compared to other combinations of organic and inorganic materials (Fig. 4d–g). Nano-alumina with a high specific surface readily interacts with the oxygen atoms in LiTFSI, thereby anchoring the lithium salt anion. The relatively low binding energy of LPSC to LiTFSI indicates that it is not as good at capturing anions as nano-alumina. In addition, our calculation of the binding energy of polymers and inorganic crystals also supports the inference in the previous section that sulfides are easy to interact with copolymers. Nano-alumina, while anchoring the anions, is almost entirely electrochemically inert. Therefore, adding alumina alone, without argyrodite-LPSC, results in stability but lower discharge capacity (Fig. S15). The ionic conductivity of L1A5A1M (0.102 mS cm−1, Fig. S16) is not significantly different from L1A1M. For the lithium symmetrical battery, A1M exhibited a cycling time of 800 h (Fig. S5a), which is not as long as the 912 h achieved by A5A1M (Fig. 4h and j). The reason why there is an inability to achieve longer cycling is the relatively poor ion transport. In the dual-filler system of sulfide and nano-alumina, both 1000 h of cycling and a polarization voltage of less than 0.1 V were simultaneously achieved (Fig. 4h–j). Similarly, in the critical current density (CCD) tests (Fig. S17a–c), after the addition of nano-alumina, the results of 0.50 mA cm−2 are higher than A1M and L1A1M. The lower CCD of A1M may be attributed to the instability of the cyano groups and the thinner polymer membrane. However, with the passivation effect of nano-alumina, the stability at higher current densities is improved. The content of chemically stable nano-alumina was controlled at 5% which is a relatively low mass ratio. In SEM images, as the proportion of nano-alumina increases from 5% to 20%, the surface gradually shows some irregular particle agglomeration (Fig. S18a–c). Solid electrolytes with 5% and 10% weight ratios of nano-alumina are more conducive to a more uniform lithium-ion flux at the interface. Distributed relaxation time (DRT) analysis was employed for impedance analysis to distinguish the origin of various ionic transportation of full-cells at different cycle numbers. In Fig. 5(a and b), the first two cycles correspond to the activation process at low current density, while starting from the third cycle, impedance begins to increase and stabilizes after 5 cycles. The time constants (τ) of 0.001 and 0.1 s peaks correspond to the interfacial charge transfer impedance of the cathode and anode, respectively. Both regions show that the impedance of L1A5A1M is smaller than that of L1A10A1M, which demonstrates that the though not exhibiting a rough surface in SEM, sample with 10% nano-alumina filler actually has an uneven surface, leading to difficulties in lithium-ion migration. 5% filler in the composite solid-state electrolyte is deemed sufficient. After cycling, there is no noticeable lithium dendrite growth or cracks on the surfaces of both the cathode and anode sides (Fig. 2d and e). To comprehensively compare the interface stability of various electrolytes, we integrated the peak areas of XPS (X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy) from the cathode and anode surfaces after cycling. Overall, due to the significant polarization and shorter cycling time of A1M, it is challenging to form a sufficiently thick passivation layer in the cycling process. In contrast, L1A1M and L1A5A1M, benefiting from enhanced ionic conductivity, exhibited a generally higher signal intensity. However, there were composition differences between them due to different components. For the cathode (Fig. 5 c and d), Li-N-C formation was observed only after the addition of sulfide, consistent with the previous AIMD results. A higher concentration of cyano groups on the cathode surface is also beneficial for the stability of NCM. Moreover, we observed that even in the case of the most unstable interface in A1M, there is no observation of the decomposition of cyano groups on the negative electrode side in the N 1s spectrum (Fig. S19). Only the signal corresponding to -NSO of LiTFSI is observed, which implies that although cyano groups are unstable on the lithium anode, the amount added during the copolymerization process is small, and the formation of a more stable SEI alleviates the decomposition of cyano groups. The presence of LiF on the cathode is surprising since it is typically associated with the anode. The lower content of LiF on the surface of L1A5A1M is attributed to the partial passivation role played by nano-alumina. For the anode (Fig. 5e and f), an increase in carbonyl groups was observed with the addition of fillers, likely due to the stabilized interface facilitating further decomposition of ester groups. The trend for the C–O bond is different, increasing with the addition of sulfide and decreasing with the addition of nano-alumina. The increase in ether groups is attributed to the accelerated degradation of ether chains through the interaction between sulfide and copolymer. The decrease is associated with the protective effect of inert oxide in the bulk phase. To be precise, besides the chemical inertness of nano-alumina, an important factor in this protection is the anchoring of TFSI− on the surface of nano-alumina. The interaction between sulfide and copolymer, along with the anchoring of the oxide, accelerates the decomposition of LiTFSI, leading to an increase in the content of LiF and C–F bonds. In conclusion, the final product L1A5A1M exhibits excellent rate performance, with discharge capacities of 180.5, 174.3, 156.7, and 132.4 mA h g−1 at 0.1, 0.2, 0.33, and 0.5 C, respectively (Fig. 6 a and b). Even after cycling at higher rates, it can still return to 0.2 C cycling for 200 cycles, maintaining a discharge capacity of 129.4 mA h g−1. Comparatively, the composite solid-state electrolyte without nano-alumina struggles to operate at high rates for an extended period. Using 0.5 C for 50 cycles as a benchmark, A1M shows a capacity retention of only 83.5%, while L1A1M reaches 94.4%, and L1A5A1M achieves a similar 94.3%, which again underscores the crucial role of sulfide in enhancing lithium-ion transport to avoid fast capacity degradation. Simultaneously, the inhibition of lithium dendrite growth by nano-alumina extends cycles from 50 to 500 without the short-circuit, demonstrating the vital role of inert oxides in improving the mechanical properties of composite solid electrolytes (Fig. 6c). The excess nano-alumina causing roughening of the interface is validated by cycling performance. After 500 cycles, L1A5A1M which poses an initial discharge capacity of 136.8 mA h g−1 maintains 91.4 mA h g−1 of its discharge capacity (Fig. 6d), while L1A10A1M which exhibits an initial discharge capacity of 114.9 mA h g−1 only retains 77 mA h g−1 (Fig. 6e). L1A20A1M experiences rapid short-circuiting within 50 cycles. Furthermore, the combination of argyrodite with nano-alumina proves superior to the direct use of the active oxide LATP (Li1.3Al0.3Ti1.7(PO4)3). This superiority arises from the unique interactions of argyrodite, as mentioned earlier, and the nano-sized nature of alumina. Another challenge lies in achieving nanoscale dispersion for LATP, leading to uneven distribution and consequently, inferior cycling performance (Fig. S20). Finally, the assembled pouch cell, after cycling, demonstrated stability under extreme conditions such as bending and puncture, highlighting its potential for scalability and safety performance. 4 Conclusions In summary, we have developed a stable composite solid-state electrolyte by combining an anode-stabilizing ether and a cathode-stabilizing cyano group. The argyrodite LPSC, through interaction with the low ion-conductive ether-nitrile copolymer, formed an intermediate phase that enhances lithium ion conduction between the two, improving capacity retention from 72.3% to 83.5% at 0.5 C after 50 cycles. In the absence of a significant increase in ionic conductivity, the inert nano-alumina additive increased lithium-ion migration, prevented excessive decomposition of the anode, and achieved an initial discharge capacity of 136.8 mA h g−1 at 0.5 C, with a better capacity retention of 94.3% after 50 cycles. The full-cell assembled with a membrane whose thickness is less than 30 μm showed no short circuits after 1000 h of electrochemical cycling. This work fills a gap in the understanding of the sulfide promotion mechanism of chemical thermodynamically stable sulfide composite solid electrolytes and demonstrates the reliability of the synergistic action of binary fillers. coredata.dc:description: Composite solid-state electrolytes represent a critical pathway that balances the interface compatibility and lithium-ion conductivity in all-solid-state batteries. The quest for stable and highly ion-conductive combinations between polymers and fillers is vital, but blind attempts are often made due to a lack of understanding of the mechanisms involved in the interaction between polymers and fillers. Herein, we employ in-situ polymerization to prepare a polymer based on an ether-nitrile copolymer with high cathode stability as the foundation and discuss the performance enhancement mechanisms of argyrodite and nano-alumina. With 1% content of sulfide interacting with the polymer at the two-phase interface, the local enhancement of lithium-ion migration capability can be achieved, avoiding the reduction in capacity due to the low ion conductivity of the passivation layer during cycling. The capacity retention after 50 cycles at 0.5 C increases from 83.5% to 94.4%. Nano-alumina, through anchoring the anions and interface inhibition functions, eventually poses an initial discharge capacity of 136.8 mA h g−1 at 0.5 C and extends the cycling time to 1000 h without short-circuiting in lithium metal batteries. Through the combined action of dual fillers on the composite solid-state electrolyte, promising insights are provided for future material design.

coredata.dc:title: Revealing the specific role of sulfide and nano-alumina in composite solid-state electrolytes for performance-reinforced ether-nitrile copolymers
